metadata.ttm:title: Adding Negotiators
metadata.ttm:desc: Authorized Negotiators may be assigned to an Offer with or without the authority to sign, and it is recommended practice to assign multiple Authorized Negotiators to the same Offer in order to ensure consistent representation throughout the Award process. Authorized Negotiators are added to an Offer when it is first created, but can also be added, removed, or have their authority status changed through the Modification process. This video will demonstrate the steps required to add Authorized Negotiators while creating an eOffer, as well as working with the Authorized Negotiator Modification.

div.p: In a previous video, we talked about the
importance of maintaining up to date Authorized
Negotiator information.
In this video, we are going to demonstrate how
an Authorized Negotiator can be added to one of
your existing GSA Schedule Contracts.Let's walk
through how you add an Authorized Negotiator to
your contract.
Again, we're going to assume for the purposes of
this video that you already have a GSA
Schedule contract in place and are somewhat familiar
with the way the eMod system works.Begin by
accessing the eOffer/eMod system, and clicking the
Sign In button under Contract Modifications.
You will be asked to confirm your digital
certificate.
Click OK if the information on the screen
is yours.
Select your DUNS number from the drop down menu or
enter it in the textbox provided, and select the
appropriate contract on the following screen.
You will also see a list of the Saved, Submitted,
Signed, and GSA-Initiated modifications on your
interface.
Because we are performing a new modification, click
"Select Contract" in the "New Modifications" table.
Within the "Administrative" mod
types, you will note the "Authorized Negotiator"
sub type.
Check this box and click "Submit Online."
Take a moment to verify that all of your corporate
information is correct.
If you notice something is incorrect, you will need
to sign out of eOffer/eMod and make the necessary
changes in CCR.
A nightly batch process will then bring your
changes in to eOffer/eMod and you will be able to
continue your modification the next day.
If everything looks accurate, click "Save and
Continue."
Click Continue to confirm the Save.On the next
screen, you will see a table identifying your
existing negotiators and their associated signing
authorities.Note that you can edit or delete any of
these negotiators by using the links to the
right.Click the "Add New Negotiator" button to
continue.Provide the information required in
the form.
This will include the negotiator's Name, Title,
Phone Number, and E-mail.
His or her Fax number is optional and may be
included if you so choose.In the Role drop
down menu, identify whether you want this
negotiator to have the authority to sign contract
modifications on your company's behalf.Remember,
if you select "Not Authorized to Sign," the
new negotiator will be able to help prepare
modifications and mod responses, but will not be
able to submit or sign off on any contractual
documents between your company and GSA.One final
note before moving on.
You MUST be sure that the authorized negotiator
information you enter is an exact match to the
information on the digital certificate of the
individual you are adding.
The importance of this will be touched on later
in the video.
With this in mind, double-check that all of
the information is correct.Click "Add this
Negotiator" when you are ready to continue.The
person you added will now appear in the table on the
previous screen.
Click "Save and Continue" to move on.Click Continue
again to confirm your changes.You may be taken
to the Upload Documents screen.
For Authorized Negotiator changes, no additional
documentation is required.
Click "Save and Continue" and "Continue" again to
confirm your changes.You will be offered one final
review of your mod.
Read the disclaimer and, if you agree, select the
"Yes" radio button.
Then click "Continue."
You have now successfully submitted your
modification.
Updates to negotiator information are handled by
batch process every morning.
You should allow 24 to 48 hours after the changes
are approved by the contracting officer for
your updates to become active within the system.
